body_html: No, it does not install a tools package; instead, the reason tools is in scope and available for import is because of the mechanics of how python setup.py develop works. The way develop works is that it sets up an egg-link in site-packages pointing to the original, root source directory of the project that was registered. This may expose more modules than would have been exposed during an actual install, since Python treats any directory containing an __init__.py as making a module available, but develop is indiscriminate and adds the entire original source directory to path.

The way develop works is that it sets up an egg-link in site-packages pointing to the original, root source directory of the project that was registered. This may expose more modules than would have been exposed during an actual install, since Python treats any directory containing an __init__.py as making a module available, but develop is indiscriminate and adds the entire original source directory to path.
body: No, it does not install a `tools` package; instead, the reason `tools` is in scope and available for import is because of the mechanics of how `python setup.py develop` works. The way develop works is that it sets up an egg-link in site-packages pointing to the original, root source directory of the project that was registered. This may expose more modules than would have been exposed during an actual install, since Python treats any directory containing an `__init__.py` as making a module available, but develop is indiscriminate and adds the entire original source directory to path.
